p: Hepatitis C virus (HCV), a member of the family Flaviviridae, genus Hepacivirus [ 1], is an important human infectious agent due to the large array of human pathologies associated to its infection which are worsened by the perspective of further increase as a public health threat for the following years ahead [ 2]. Approximately 170 million persons are thought to be persistently infected [ 3, 4] and at least 80% will develop severe diseases including chronic hepatitis, cirrhosis or liver cancer [ 5].
